text: I'm Matt ruse the frugal traveler for
the New York Times whenever I'm
traveling abroad and I tell people I
come from New York they always have the
same reaction Oh big city isn't it
expensive and I always tell them the
same thing New York is really just a
city of small manageable neighborhoods
and it's not expensive at all if you
know where to go to prove it I set out
with my wife Jean to have a tourist
style weekend in New York on a budget of
just five hundred dollars a reasonably
priced bed of course is always the
biggest hurdle but one of the cheapest
hotels in town is also one of the most
famous the Chelsea Dylan Thomas Mark
Twain and Sid Vicious all called at home
as did legions of lesser-known artists
many of whom donated their works as
payment not being artists however we had
to pay 150 dollars a night sounds like a
lot right it's not well not in New York
at least the Chelsea isn't fancy but it
is clean and comfortable the only
drawback you're sharing a bathroom
getting around New York on a budget is
relatively easy walking is of course
free but for covering distance rely on
the subway for the most part G and I
spent the weekend downtown that is below
union square where four times a week the
green market is in full swing
the greenmarket does offer free
entertainment and occasionally free
advice sometimes I go to a lot of
openings you know because they they have
free free wine and beer actually there
are tons of free activities like hanging
out at hudson river park on Manhattan's
far west side what was once the gritty
port area is now placed a jog sunbathe
or just watch the boats go by these are
three buildings designed by the
architect Richard Meier the meijer
towers are not for the frugal and the
super chef jean-georges Vongerichten has
his Perry Street restaurant there but
there's a secret if you go to George
George at lunchtime they have a
three-course meal for twenty four
dollars and you just can't beat it you
can't beat it just east of the
waterfront is Greenwich Village where to
our surprise we found a weekly flea
market we hadn't known anything about
clear frames are in but it's a nice
contrast to the gentrification of the
neighborhood where fashion designers
Marc Jacobs and ralph lauren and the
infamous Magnolia Bakery dominated
that night Jean and I headed down to the
lower east side where we had our first
date a whole decade ago one of the
neighborhood's new club was supposedly
giving away free beer between midnight
and 1am but I wasn't about to violate my
Cardinal law of nightlife never wait
behind velvet rose I did however ask
some NYU students for their own frugal
recommendations a great cheap lacy dis
pommes frites on seventh Street and
second Avenue it's basically Belgian
fries with a billion different dipping
sauces but it's really cool it's open
until like four I am on the weekends and
it's a great place to hang out this area
used to be underground and therefore
cheap but now on weekends it can feel a
bit like a zoo still some of the old
neighborhood survives katz's deli for
example and some ancient street art
hmm I wonder who lived here as
mainstream as the neighborhood is now
it's still the best place to find the
unusually this is a recreation of a
beetle nut booth in Taiwan betelnut
isn't a mild stimulant that sold all
over Asia and specifically in Taiwan
it's evolved where it's sold in this
manner with scantily clad girl in a
glass booth and lots of neon and usually
she's on the highway or the street
corner selling it after a couple days in
men hats I'm always happy to get back to
Brooklyn the calmer cooler and more
affordable borough in the sunset park
neighborhood there's a huge trend just
like Manhattan minus the tourists the
Pacific Khanna is our new favorite spot
for dim sum the traditional Chinese
brunch our friends Ted and amber joined
us for lots of dumplings radish cakes
and of course chicken feet all right so
it is that eat a chicken for sure
first thing is you get it in the top
sticks and there's it's kind of rubbery
that's where all the fun is there's all
these little joints here you kind of
nibble off the joints I personally need
to vote but you don't have to go here we
go
I fit yum yum even better it costs less
than ten dollars a person how do you say
frugal in Chinese finally it was back to
South Brooklyn for me and gene and I
spent the afternoon hanging out at our
local Yacht Club is an outdoor beer
garden that's about six and a seven
months a year and opens up in a phone
goes down and knocked older it's kind of
like your backyard a lot of people in
Brooklyn at a backyard name for the
Gowanus Canal it's a relatively
inexpensive place to drink and an even
better place to meet people from your
past ranches actually every time I come
back to New York and meet new people and
friendship like much else in new york
city doesn't cost a thing for the New
York Times my hometown paper I'm Matt
gross the frugal traveler
